runs.text: Explain that many words are related because they come from the same root, like
the root. Tell students that knowing the root word can help them read and spell words.
(root = hope). Point out the spelling change in
and how knowing the root helps you pronounce the word correctly. Contrast
Have students find the root in these word pairs:
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you hear thats different in these two words? What do you see thats different?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then reblending the word together.
Remind students that many words are related because they come from the same root. Often, knowing the root word can help us read, spell, and pronounce words. Model identifying the root word
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.
When completed, have students select two words with the same related root.
Ask them to write a sentence using both words on paper or a dry-erase board.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Guide students to slowly say the word
focusing on the two parts that will help them remember the spelling:
Dictate the following words for students to spell:

. Write the words on the board for students to self-correct. Note on each students Student Observation Form sound-spellings they struggle with. Include more words with these sound-spellings in upcoming lessons.
on the board. Read each word aloud and have students repeat. Remind students that many words have the same root.
in each word. Remind students that knowing the root word can help them read, spell, and pronounce words.
Continue by having students identify the root word in these word pairs:
Display each word, and guide students to read it.
Model how to sort the words
Have student partners sort the remaining words at their seats.
When completed, have students tell you how to sort the words in the pocket chart. Then have students chorally read the words in each column of the sort.
Ask students what they notice about the words.

Encourage students to look for words with the same root while reading. Highlight these words as you encounter them.
Read Aloud: Exploring the Past Through Artifacts
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words studying, artifacts, preserved, purposes, and fascinated, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
on the board. Remind students that many words are related because they come from the same root. Often, knowing the root word can help us read, spell, and pronounce words.
were added to the root word

Use the new blending words to apply the skill. For the first time through, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Then discuss key features of each word to focus students attention on known (regular) and unknown (irregular) word parts.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.

to make each word. Have students identify the root word

Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud. Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then reblending the word together.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time.
Point to and say each word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Read, Build, Write: across, become, complete, during, happened, hundred, problem, toward, study, wind

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g., I wish I had one hundred_____.).
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.
on the board. Remind students that many words are related because they share the same root word. Write the words
. Point out that these are related words because they both contain the root word
. Guide students to create more related root words by adding suffixes, such as
. Discuss the spelling change required to make each new word. List the words and have students read them.
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. When completed, guide students to find and underline all the root words. Then have them put a box around all the words with the ending
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.
write, rewrite, handwrite, prewrite, writer, typewriter (transition to multisyllabic)
State the Letter Cards to change. For example, say:
to make a related root word. What word did you make?
Repeat, but dont tell students which letters to change. For example, say:

Display the photo on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words retrieved, selected, included, miniature, and unfamiliar, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.

Use the Lesson 6 blending words to quickly review the skill.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Revisit the sentences to model sentence expanding by adding details. Have students expand one of their sentences
Read Aloud: Egyptian Pyramids and Mummies
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words wonder, honor, inserted, removed, prevent, and hidden, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Remind students that many words are related because they have the same root word. Display the words
. Have students create related root words by adding prefixes, suffixes, and inflectional endings to each root word to form new words. Record students words on the board.
Have students select two related root words from the list and write sentences for them.
This word names what you do with scissors.
to make a word that means cut again.
to make a word that means not cut.
Replace the prefix in uncut to make a word that means cut ahead of time.
Take away the prefix in precut and add an ending to make a word that means chopping.
Change the ending of cutting to name something that cuts.
